item.title: N-Gram Language Models
item.description:
Equation

$$ \boxed{ P(X_1, \dots, X_n) = P(X_1) P(X_2 | X_1) P(X_3 | X_{1:2} \dots P(X_n | X_1:{n-1}) } $$$$ \begin{equation} P(X_1, \dots, X_n) = \prod_{k=1}^{n} P(X_k | X_{1:k-1}) \end{equation} $$

We apply this to words:

\begin{equation} P(w_{1:n}) = P(w_1) P(w_2|w_1) P(w_3|w_{1:2}) \dots P(w_n|w_{1:n-1}) \end{equation}

\begin{equation} P(w_{1:n}) = \prod_{k=1}^{n} P(w_k|w_{1:k-1}) \end{equation}

$$P(w_n|w_{n-1})$$

\begin{equation} P(w_n|w_{1:n-1}) \approx P(w_n|w_{n-1}) \end{equation}

An example of a \textbf{Markov assumption} is when the probability of a word depends only on the previous word in the case of a bigram, a trigram, and a n-gram looks two words, and $n-1$ words into the past, respectively.
